Now, let's consider what possible genotype combinations could lead to this outcome. If both parents are heterozygous (Bb), then each parent can produce a 50% chance of passing on the dominant allele (B) or the recessive (b). When you cross two heterozygotes (Bb × Bb), the possible gametes are B and b. So the Punnett square for this cross would be:

          | B      | b
        ----------------
         B     | BB    | Bb
         b      | Bb    | bb

So, the possible offspring genotypes are BB (25%), Bb (50%), and bb (25%). But wait, the problem states that three-quarters are black (BB and Bb) and a quarter are white (bb). That fits perfectly because BB and Bb make up 75% of the offspring, and bb makes up 25%. Therefore, if both parents are Bb, that would explain the observed traits.

But let me double-check the other options just to be sure. Option C was bb × Bb, which would also give the same 75% black and 25% white ratio. Wait, no—that's not right. Because when you cross a homozygous recessive (bb) with a heterozygote (Bb), the offspring will always receive one b allele. So all offspring would be Bb, meaning they all have the dominant trait—black. That wouldn't fit the given data where some are black and some are white. So option C might actually be incorrect because it would result in a 100% black coat phenotype instead of 75% black and 25% white.

Wait, but earlier I thought that both Bb × Bb and bb × Bb would lead to the same 75% black to 25% white ratio. Let me re-examine that. For Bb × Bb, as I did before, it results in 75% BB and Bb and 25% bb. But for bb × Bb, since the bb parent gives only b alleles, every offspring would get at least one b, making them Bb, hence all black. That doesn't match the problem statement. So maybe my initial thought was wrong; perhaps only Bb × Bb leads to the correct ratio.

Alternatively, looking back at the original reasoning, both Bb × Bb and bb × Bb might seem plausible, but upon closer inspection, only Bb × Bb produces the desired 75% black and 25% white. Whereas bb × Bb would produce all black, which doesn't fit the data. Therefore, the correct answer must be that both parents are Bb, making their offspring 75% black and 25% white.

The correct answer is H

The first thing to note is that for a 3:1 ratio in a dihybrid cross (though here it's just one gene), but wait, no—it’s actually a monohybrid cross because there's only one gene involved. Wait, no—actually, since each parent can contribute only one allele for the same gene, the possible combinations are limited. So, if both parents are heterozygous (Bb), then the possible gametes they can produce are B and b. When you cross them, each parent can give either B or b, leading to four possible combinations: BB, Bb, Bb, and bb. Thus, the offspring would have the following genotype frequencies: 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. But when we translate that into coat colors, since B is dominant and b is recessive, those would correspond to black, black, and white respectively. Therefore, the phenotypic ratio would be 3:1 (three black and one white). That matches exactly what's given in the problem statement.

Looking back at the options, option G is "Bb × Bb," which fits perfectly. Now, I need to make sure that other options don't also lead to a 3:1 ratio. For example, option F is "Bb × bb." If one parent is Bb and the other is bb, their possible gametes are B and b. So, the offspring would receive either B or b from each parent. This leads to the possibilities: BB (B from Bb and B from bb; B from Bb and b from bb), Bb (B from Bb and b from bb; b from Bb and B from bb), and bb (b from Bb and b from bb). Therefore, the genotypes would be 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. Converting to coat colors, that becomes 25% black and 75% white. That doesn't match the problem statement's 3:1 ratio. So, option F is incorrect.

Option D is "bb × bb." Both parents are homozygous recessive, meaning they can't produce any B alleles. All offspring would be bb, which translates to 100% white coats. So, that's not matching either. Option E is "bb × BB." Similarly, if one parent is bb and the other is BB, the offspring will always get the B allele from the BB parent and the b from the bb parent. So, all offspring would be Bb, which means 75% black and 25% white. Again, that's different from the 3:1 ratio.

Option H is "BB × Bb." Here, one parent is homozygous dominant (BB), and the other is heterozygous (Bb). The gametes would be B from BB and B and b from Bb. So, the possible offspring genotypes are BB (from BB + B) and Bb (from BB + b and Bb + b). Thus, 50% BB and 50% Bb. Converting to coat colors, 50% black and 50% white. Not matching.

Option I is "BB × bb." Similar reasoning as option E. All offspring would be Bb, resulting in 75% black and 25% white. Incorrect.

Option J is "BB × BB." Both parents are homozygous dominant. They will produce only B alleles. So, all offspring are BB, resulting in 100% black. Incorrect.

Now looking at option C: "bb × Bb." One parent is homozygous recessive (bb), and the other is heterozygous (Bb). The gametes from the bb parent are always b, while the gametes from the Bb parent are B and b. So, the possible offspring genotypes are Bb (from Bb + b) and bb (from Bb + b). The phenotype ratio would be 75% black and 25% white. Again, not matching.

Option B: "BB × BB and Bb × bb." Hmm, this seems more complicated. It looks like option B lists two separate crosses: BB × BB and Bb × bb. The first cross would produce 100% BB offspring, all black. So combining, the total would be 100% + 75% black and 25% white? No, that still exceeds 100%. Alternatively, maybe it's an error in how the crosses are presented. Perhaps the intended setup was that each parent produces gametes, and the combined offspring would be calculated across both pairs. But without further clarity, it's hard to say. However, in reality, a single cross involves both parents, so option B doesn't represent a single cross scenario. Hence, it's unlikely to be the correct answer.

bb (from b and b).

Bb → black,
bb → white.

BB → black,

Bb → black,

bb → white.

chunk_resampled: So, thinking about possible genotypes for the parents.
rollout:
So, thinking about possible genotypes for the parents. If the parents are both heterozygous (Bb), then when they produce gametes, each can give either B or b. So the Punnett square would look like:

Parent 1: Bb
Parent 2: Bb

The possible combinations are:
- B (from Parent 1) + B (from Parent 2) = BB → black
- B (from Parent 1) + b (from Parent 2) = Bb → black
- b (from Parent 1) + B (from Parent 2) = Bb → black
- b (from Parent 1) + b (from Parent 2) = bb → white

Out of four possible offspring, three are BB or Bb (so black) and one is bb (white). That matches exactly with the given data: ¾ black and ¼ white. Therefore, if the parents are both Bb (heterozygous), their offspring will have a 3:1 ratio. This seems straightforward.

Now, looking back at the options provided:

A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb  
C. bb × Bb  
D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB  
F. Bb × bb  
G. Bb × BB  
H. BB × Bb  
I. BB × bb  
J. BB × BB  

From my analysis, option A (Bb × Bb) produces the correct 3:1 ratio. Let me quickly check other options just to be sure. For example, option F is Bb × bb. If one parent is Bb and the other is bb, the possible gametes from Bb are B and b (50% each), and from bb, only b. So the offspring would get either Bb or bb. The probability of Bb (and thus black) is 50%, and bb (white) is also 50%. But our data shows 75% black and 25% white, not equal halves. So option F doesn't fit. Similarly, option G is Bb × BB. Each parent can contribute either B or b for the first gene, but since the second parent is BB, all its gametes are B. So the offspring would have either B (from BB) + B (from Bb) = BB (black) or B (from BB) + b (from Bb) = Bb (black). So 100% black, which doesn't match. Option H is BB × Bb. Similar logic as F: 50% Bb and 50% BB, leading to 50% black and 50% white. Not matching. Option C is bb × Bb. Offspring would have either bb (white) or Bb (black), same as F. Option E is bb × BB, same as G. Option D is BB × BB and Bb × bb—wait, that's actually multiple crosses. It says "BB × BB and Bb × bb"—but this might imply separate crosses, but in any case, the individual crosses wouldn't lead to the required ratio. Because if you do BB × BB, all offspring are BB (black). If you do Bb × bb, half are Bb (black) and half are bb (white). So combined, the ratio would be more than 75% black, which doesn't match. So the correct parents must be both heterozygous. Looking back, yes, option A fits perfectly.
</think>
The correct answer is A

The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white).

rollout:
So, if the ratio is 3:1, that typically means a dihybrid cross where both parents contribute alleles such that each child has an independent 50% chance of getting the dominant or recessive form. But wait, since there's only one gene involved here, it's actually a monohybrid cross. Monohybrid crosses usually produce a 3:1 ratio when the parents are heterozygous, like Bb × Bb. Let me think about why. Each parent can give either B or b. So, possible combinations are BB, Bb, and bb. When you cross them, the Punnett square shows four outcomes:

- BB × BB → BB (25%)
- BB × Bb → Bb (50%)
- BB × bb → Bb (50%)
- Bb × Bb → 25%
- Bb × bb → 25%
- bb × bb → bb (25%)

Wait, no, that's not quite right. Actually, it should be more precise. If both parents are Bb, then their gametes are B and b each. So the Punnett square would look like:

          | B   | b
        -----------------
        B      | BB | Bb
        b      | Bb | bb

Each cell represents a possible genotype for the offspring. Now, calculating the phenotypic ratio: 
- BB and Bb will show black (since B is dominant).
- bb will show white.

Looking at the counts:
- BB: 25%
- Bb: 50%
- bb: 25%

So, the phenotypic ratio is 25% : 50% : 25%, which simplifies to 1:2:1, but often presented as 3:1 when considering the proportion of each phenotype relative to the total. Wait, maybe I got confused earlier. Let me clarify: in a monohybrid cross with a 3:1 ratio, each parent must be heterozygous (Bb), because only then do they produce equal chances of passing on B or b. So the expected phenotypic ratio would indeed be 3:1, meaning three times as many B_ as _bb.

Now, looking back at the options provided:

The question asks which combination of parents would result in the observed 3:1 ratio. So let me go through the options one by one.

Option A: Bb × Bb — That's exactly what I just thought about. Both parents are Bb, leading to a 3:1 ratio. This seems correct.

Option B: BB × BB and Bb × bb — Hmm, the first part is BB × BB. Crossing two homozygotes for the same gene would always result in BB. The second parent is Bb × bb. What does that yield? Let's compute. Bb × bb.

Gametes from Bb are B and b; from bb, only b. So offspring genotypes are Bb and bb. Phenotypes: Bb is black, bb is white. So the ratio would be 1:1 (BB:0, Bb:50%, bb:50%). Not matching the required 3:1.

Option C: bb × Bb — Similar to option A. Bb × bb would produce 50% Bb and 50% bb. Again, 1:1 ratio. Not 3:1.

Option D: bb × bb — Both parents are homozygous recessive. All offspring would be bb, showing white coat. So 100% white. Definitely doesn't match.

Option E: BB × bb — First parent is BB, second is bb. All offspring would be Bb, which is black. Again, 100% black. Doesn't fit.

Option F: Bb × bb — As above, this gives 50% Bb (black) and 50% bb (white). Ratio 1:1. Doesn't match.

Option G: Bb × BB — Same as A, both Bb and BB. So 3:1 ratio. Correct.

Option H: BB × Bb — Same as Bb × BB, also 3:1. Correct.

Option I: BB × bb — All offspring are Bb, which is black. 100% black. Doesn't fit.

Option J: BB × BB — All offspring are BB, 100% black. Doesn't fit.

From this analysis, options A, G, and H all involve Bb × something else. Wait, no—let me double-check.

Actually, in my initial assessment, option A is Bb × Bb, while options G and H are Bb × BB. So both G and H are possible. However, the question specifies "the most likely," implying a unique answer. Wait, perhaps I made a mistake.

Let me re-examine the options. Oh, wait—the user listed the options as A to J, with some being duplicates. For example, option G is Bb × BB, and option H is BB × Bb, which is essentially the same as A but swapped. Since parents are interchangeable in crosses, Bb × BB and BB × Bb both lead to the same offspring genotypes—50% Bb and 50% BB. Therefore, both G and H would result in the same phenotypic ratio. But the question is asking for the most likely pair, implying a specific combination. However, in reality, any of A, G, or H would work.

</think>
The correct answer is A

Black hair coat is dominant over white hair coat. Three quarters of the offspring have black coats, and one quarter have white coats. The genotypes of the parents were most likely

A. Bb × Bb

B. BB × BB and Bb × bb

C. bb × Bb

D. bb × bb

E. bb × BB

F. Bb × bb

G. Bb × BB

H. BB × Bb

I. BB × bb

J. BB × BB

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). 

Now, let's think about possible parent combinations. The options given are A to J, with various genotype pairs. Each option represents the possible genotype combinations of the parents. For example, option A is Bb × Bb, meaning both parents are heterozygous for the dominant trait. Option H is BB × bb, where one parent is homozygous dominant and the other is homozygous recessive.

Let's go through each option systematically:

Option A: Bb × Bb  
Each parent can produce gametes B and b in equal proportions. So when they mate, the F1 generation will be 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. But wait, the problem states that the parents themselves must carry certain alleles because their offspring show a 3:1 ratio. If both parents are Bb, then the expected ratio would indeed be 3:1 (BB, Bb, bb). However, if the parents are different, like Bb × bb, then the F1 would be 25% Bb and 75% bb, leading to a 1:3 ratio. That doesn't match the observed 3:1.

Option B: BB × BB and Bb × bb  
This seems complicated because there are multiple possible parent types here. The first part is a BB parent, which only produces B gametes. The second part includes a Bb (producing 50% B and 50% b) and a bb (producing only b). But since the parents are mixed (one BB and one Bb/bb?), how does that affect the offspring? This might complicate things further and probably won't lead to a 3:1 ratio unless specific conditions are met, but I don't see an obvious way this leads to 3:1.

Option C: bb × Bb  
Here, one parent is homozygous recessive (bb), and the other is heterozygous (Bb). When they mate, the possible gametes from the Bb parent are B and b, while the bb parent only gives b. So the F1 would be 50% Bb and 50% bb. Wait, but according to the problem statement, both parents are likely to be contributing to the F2 generation. So maybe I need to consider the F2 generation instead of F1. Let me correct that. The actual parent-crossing is done to get F1, but the question is about the parents' genotypes. Alternatively, perhaps the question is considering the F2 generation's ratio, but no, the question says "the scientist carried out a cross," implying the parents themselves. Hmm, maybe I'm getting confused here.

Wait, the problem states that both parents are guinea pigs with black coats. So their genotypes are likely diploid. The coat color being determined by one gene implies that each parent has two copies of the same allele. So possible genotypes for each parent are BB, Bb, or bb. Now, the observed offspring ratio is ¾ black and ¼ white. Let's think about the possible combinations of parents.

If both parents are Bb (option A), then the F1 would be 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. The phenotypic ratio would be 3:1 as desired. But if one parent is Bb and the other is bb (option C), then the F1 would be 50% Bb and 50% bb, giving a phenotypic ratio of 1:1, not 3:1. Similarly, if one parent is BB and the other is Bb (option D), then the F1 would be 50% BB and 50% Bb, resulting in a 1:1 ratio. Not matching.

Option E: BB × bb  
Here, one parent is homozygous dominant (BB), producing only B gametes, and the other is homozygous recessive (bb), producing only b gametes. So all offspring will be Bb, which means all will be brown (assuming B is dominant). That would give a 100% brown coat, which doesn't match the observed ¾ black and ¼ white. So option E is out.

Option F: Bb × bb  
In this case, one parent is Bb and the other is bb. As above, the F1 would be 50% Bb and 50% bb, giving a 1:1 ratio, not 3:1. So option F is incorrect.

Option G: Bb × BB  
Same as option E, just swapped. One parent is Bb (produces B and b), and the other is BB (only B). All offspring would be Bb, hence all brown. Doesn't fit the 3:1 ratio.

Option H: BB × Bb  
One parent is BB (only B gamete), and the other is Bb (produces B and b). So all offspring will be Bb, same as option F and E. No match.

Option I: BB × bb  
As discussed earlier, this results in all Bb (brown) offspring. No match.

Option J: BB × BB  
Both parents are homozygous dominant (BB). Their F1 would all be BB, giving 100% brown, which is not the case.

So, going back, the only viable option that gives a 3:1 ratio is option A: Bb × Bb. Both parents are heterozygous for the dominant trait. The F1 would be 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. Phenotypically, BB and Bb would express the dominant coat color (black), while bb would be white. Hence, 3/4 black and 1/4 white. This matches the given data perfectly.
</think>
The correct answer is A

rollout:
So, let's think about possible parent combinations. Each parent must contribute alleles such that when combined, they produce a certain ratio of phenotypes. Let's consider each option provided:

Option A: Bb × Bb. So, if both parents are heterozygous (Bb), then their offspring would be 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bB (which is the same as 25% bb since B and b are just alleles). But wait, since Bb × Bb leads to a 3:1 ratio because each gamete can combine with the other parent. Specifically, the possible offspring genotypes would be BB (25%), Bb (50%), and bb (25%). Converting this to phenotype, since B is dominant, all the Bb and BB individuals will show black, while the bb will show white. That gives a 3:1 ratio of black to white, which matches the problem description perfectly. So this seems like a strong candidate.

Let me check other options quickly to make sure there's no better answer.

Option B: BB × BB and Bb × bb. If one parent is homozygous dominant (BB) and another is heterozygous (Bb), the offspring would get either BB from the first parent and B from the second, making BB; or B from the first and Bb from the second, making Bb. So the possible offspring genotypes are BB (25%) and Bb (75%). When converted to phenotype, all would be black, resulting in a 100% black ratio. This doesn't match the given 3:1 ratio, so this option is incorrect.

Option C: bb × Bb. Similar to Option A but flipped. Both parents are Bb, so the same reasoning applies here too. The offspring would be 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. Again, this results in a 3:1 ratio of black to white. However, looking back, Option A is also correct, so maybe both A and C are valid? Wait, no—the parents in Option C are bb and Bb, so their possible offspring would be Bb (from B and b) and bb (from b and b). So the genotypes are 25% Bb and 75% bb. Wait, actually, no—each parent can give either allele. So the possible outcomes are B from the first and B from the second → BB; B from the first and b from the second → Bb; b from the first and B from the second → Bb; and b from the first and b from the second → bb. Therefore, the proportions are BB:50%, Bb:50%, and bb:0%. Wait, that doesn't sound right. No, more accurately, each parent can produce gametes independently. For bb × Bb, the first parent (bb) produces only bb gametes, and the second (Bb) produces B and b gametes in equal amounts. So the offspring would receive B from the second parent and b from the first, leading to Bb (50%) and b from the first and whatever the other parent gives, which is only bb. So the offspring would be 50% Bb and 50% bb. Thus, the phenotype would be 50% black (Bb) and 50% white (bb), not matching the 3:1 ratio. So Option C isn't correct.

Wait, now I'm confused because earlier I thought Option A was correct, but upon closer examination, perhaps I made an error. Let me clarify:

In Option A: Bb × Bb. The parents are both Bb, so each can produce four types of gametes: B, B, b, b. So the Punnett square would be:

- First B from Bb × Second B: BB
- First B from Bb × Second b: Bb
- First b from Bb × Second B: Bb
- First b from Bb × Second b: bb

So the proportion is 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. Phenotype-wise, BB and Bb are black, and bb is white. So the ratio is 3:1, which matches the problem statement. So Option A is correct.

But earlier, I thought Option C might be correct but realized it wasn't. Similarly, checking Option G: Bb × BB. Wait, but that's similar to Option A. Let me see why I wrote H before, probably a typo.

So, going back, the correct answer should be Option A.
</think>
The correct answer is A

Case 1: Both parents are BB (BB × BB). All offspring will be BB, meaning they'll all have black coats. That doesn't match the given ratio, so this case is incorrect.

Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white).
chunk_resampled: Now, let's think about how Punnett squares work here.
rollout:
Now, let's think about how Punnett squares work here. If there's a 3:1 ratio, that implies that each parent must be heterozygous for the coat color gene because if both parents are homozygous (BB or bb), their offspring would all be BB or all be bb, resulting in a 100% dominant or recessive phenotype. But in our case, the offspring are not all the same; they're split into two groups based on coat color. So the parents can't both be homozygous because that wouldn't produce a mix. Therefore, both parents must carry at least one dominant and one recessive allele. Wait, but wait—no, actually, since the coat color is determined by a single gene, the possible combinations depend on whether the alleles are present.

Let me consider the possible genotype pairs given in the options:

A. Bb × Bb
So both parents are heterozygous. Their offspring would have a 25% chance of being BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. That gives a 3:1 ratio when considering the coat color (since BB and Bb are black, and bb is white). That fits perfectly with the ¾ black and ¼ white observed here. So option A seems correct.

But let me check the other options just to make sure I'm not missing something.

B. BB × BB and Bb × bb
If one parent is homozygous BB and the other is Bb × bb (a dihybrid cross?), then the offspring would include some BB, some Bb, some Bb, and some bb. Calculating the exact ratios might get complicated, but I don't think it would give exactly ¾ black and ¼ white. It might vary more, perhaps. Also, the parents aren't all necessarily contributing randomly unless specified otherwise. But without knowing the parents' types, maybe it's less likely. But I already considered A as a possibility, and it does fit.

C. bb × Bb
Here, one parent is homozygous recessive (bb) and the other is Bb. When you cross them, every offspring will have at least one B allele (from Bb) and one b allele (from bb). So all offspring will be Bb, meaning all will have black coats. That doesn't match the observed ¾ black and ¼ white. So C is incorrect.

D. bb × bb
Both parents are homozygous recessive. All their offspring will be bb, so all white coats. Definitely incorrect.

E. bb × BB
Similar to option D, both parents are homozygous, leading to all offspring being bb. Incorrect.

F. Bb × bb
Same as E, all offspring would be Bb (black), so incorrect.

G. Bb × BB
Again, all offspring would be Bb (black), incorrect.

H. BB × Bb
Crossing a homozygote BB with a heterozygote Bb. The offspring would be 50% BB (black) and 50% Bb (black). So all offspring would be black, which is incorrect.

I. BB × bb
This is similar to H and G. Cross BB (homozygous dominant) with bb (homozygous recessive). All offspring would be Bb, hence black. Incorrect.

J. BB × BB
Both parents are homozygous dominant. All offspring would be BB, so all black. Incorrect.

Wait, did I miss any? Oh no, I've covered all possibilities where parents are either homozygous or heterozygous. Only option A results in a ¾ black and ¼ white ratio. So I think option A is the right answer.
</think>
The correct answer is A
